I learned about pressure more than 50 years ago. At that time, mm/Hg was the only unit of measure for pressure. To this date, all my barometers and other pressure gauges have a mm/Hg scale, because it is the only unit can grasp without thinking. Note that "Hg" is the chemical symbol for mercury, called Hydragirium in Latin.
The generations before myself, they had their gauges with a "Torr" scale, where 1 Torr = 760 mm/Hg = 1 atm. "Torr" comes from Torricelli, the Italian inventor of the mercury barometer.

Actually, you can't reach the absolute max height based on pressure alone (vacuum at the air/water interface), since water boils at around 2 or 3 kPa at room temperature. That's 2/3% of Earth atmospheric pressure, or 20/30cm before the 10.3m mark. Steam will continuously replace what the vacuum pump tries to take out. You don't get this problem with mercury since it's hard to boil, even in vacuum.

So I don't wanna be THAT kind of guy but i think that, other than not considering the happening of cavitation, as many of you have said already, he is also neglecting viscous effects. I made couple of calculations and here's what i got.
So let's say the fluid is water. From now on I am gonna use SI units of measure only because I am european, sorry if that bothers you lol. Anyways, to calculate the max height we can use the generalized version of Bernoulli equation: p1+0.5(density)*v1^2+(specific weight)*h1= p2+0.5(density)*v2^2+(specific weight)*h2+(specif weight)*hl, where hl is the head loss due to viscous effects. Let's say that water is moving with constant speed at 0,6 m/s (in the video the guy has made the fluid reach him after 10 seconds with a 6m long tube, so seems like a reasonable assumption). We can express the hl in terms of the friction factor: hl= f*0.5*V^2*h*(1/g*D), where D is the diameter (I used D=5mm). Now if we consider that initially the fluid has 0 velocity, 0 height and 0 gauge pressure, we can easily apply Bernoulli with losses. First we need to calculate f. I used the Colebrook correlation considering plastic as hydraulically smooth, to find f = 0.05. Last thing we need to set a minimum preassure, which would be the one at which cavitation occurs. For 25C, pmin= 3170 Pa so a gauge preassure of -98130 Pa. Now we can solve Bernoulli and find hmax=9m.
Hope you enjoyed and let me know if you think something's wrong!!!

I'm super late to the party but theres one small issue with your theoretical calculation. (Please forgive me if someone else already mentioned this) But there is an additional limiting factor on vacuum pulling a liquid known as vapor pressure. For any given liquid its vapor pressure marks a point where if the pressure on the liquid drops below that point the liquid will simply start to boil rather than expand upward. The means a perfect vacuum is impossible so the pressure difference will be less than assumed in this video. Water has a vapor pressure of 2.4kPa so its theoretical maximum height would be a function of (atmospheric pressure - max(vapor pressure, applied pressure))*g*h.
It only makes a few % of difference with water but for some liquids it's a pretty massive limiting factor.

The moment you put a straw in your mouth and start sucking, you create a negative pressure (a pressure less than that of the atmospheric pressure), relative to the pressure exerted by the liquid coke which the other end of the straw is in, which moves the liquid up the straw and into your mouth. The speed and intensity at which this negative pressure is kept, and it's magnitude, determine how quickly the liquid will go up the straw. That's how a straw works. It's the same physics used to understand the lungs, because basically that's how our lungs also work. We create a negative pressure in our lungs when we inhale (expanding the lungs), which causes air on the outside, which is at atmospheric pressure, to get sucked into your lungs. Physics is fun isn't it guys?

The 7 meters shows that the created 'vacuum' is at 2.5/7= 0.35 atm.

A healthy lung of a man can reduce the volume from 3 to maximum 0.6 liters. By expanding an air filled lung of 0.6 liters to 3 liters the atmospheric nitrogen/oxygen pressure in the lung can drop from 1 atm to 0.6/3.1=0.2 atm. Since water is always present there is always 0.06 atm back ground pressure. So a man could achieve, without a leak from nose of mouth, a level of 0.26 atm vacuum which corresponds to 7.7 meters.

The achieved 7 meters is thus amazing good!

10.3 meters is only the “theoretical” maximum. It is impossible to pull a perfect vacuum with a liquid. The maximum has to be adjusted by the vapor pressure of the liquid being used. Water has a significant vapor pressure in this case and would reduce the maximum possible. You may have seen this in science class by boiling water at room temperature by placing it in a vacuum.  Mercury also has the same problem but has a much lower Vapor pressure. Vapor pressure of water in is about 20 mmhg and mercury is about 0.002 mmhg at room temperature.

Just a note:
The maximum height depends on the net downwards force acting on the fluid. This means that altitude (gravitational force) and rotational velocity (centripetal force) both have an effect —albeit extremely small effect— on the maximum height a fluid can move up in a vacuum whilst on Earth.

While the width of the tube does not matter in an ideal scenario, in a real scenario, surface tension can significantly increase the distance, and with a narrow enough tube, capillary action could travel extremely high, without even an active vacuum.

Ok, but you left capillary action out of your equation. The smaller the inside diameter of the tube the easier and higher you can pull it with the same amount of vacuum. Water flows 900 times faster through a nano-tube than it will through your kitchen plumbing(ted talk-the weirdness of water may be the answer). In a garden hose the capillary action will cause the water to rise up the wall of the hose, about a millimeter or two at normal atmospheric pressure. But in a wine vinometer ( about a 1 mm diameter tube) the water will rise about 10-15 mm. In a redwood tree the capillaries are about a molecule in diameter and water will rise over 300' up, but that in part may be due to the restructuring of water as well. That is hundreds of feet higher than the theoretical maximum height a vacuum can raise a liquid. There is room to expand this video!

The actual height you can suck water up through a straw (assuming capillary effect is negligible) is 10.0 meters. The thing that was missing in the equation at the end of the video is the vapor pressure of water. You can't get a true vacuum that is adjacent to the free surface of water. As the pressure decreases, the water will vaporize and stabilize the pressure. At room temperature, this is about 3.169kPa. The final equation should be modified to (101325-3169)/(1000*9.8)=10.0m. This is known as Net Positive Suction Head and is used quite extensively in pump calculations.

That was certainly clever making the diameter large enough so that the head loss was negligible. If we include head loss (major loss) effects and assume the flow is laminar, the basic equation is
(atmospheric pressure)=rho*g*(headloss + height)
where headloss = 128*viscosity*legnth of pipe*flow velocity/(pi*density*gravity*diameter^4)
If we assume that the density, viscosity of the soda ~ water and temperature is ~ 20 C, the average flow velocity ~ 1 cm^3/s when it was moving, then subbing in, we get about 10.2 m as the maximum height for 5.5 mm diameter.
Contrast that with a 3 mm diameter and you get a headloss of about 9.65 m.

Great video guys! I'm not too hot on physics, but I just wanted to point out that sucking through a normal size/length straw doesn't use your lungs or diaphragm, but instead relies on the air pressure in the length of the straw being decreased by increasing the volume of space in your mouth alone. You start with a relatively closed space with your lips creating a seal around the straw at the front of your mouth and the body of your tongue pushed to the roof of your mouth, cheeks close. Sucking begins when the tongue draws down from the roof of the mouth, making the oral space slightly bigger, (a larger volume to fill which lowers the pressure and causes a pressure gradient which the liquid moves to fill? - correct me if I'm wrong). You can test this by sucking liquid up a normal straw whilst breathing through your nose still. If you were creating the pressure gradient with your lungs by moving your diaphragm down, you wouldn't be able to breathe through your nose because your throat would have blocked the airway to allow for a pressure gradient to build. Also, you would very quickly have fluid in your lungs - once the air runs out you'd just be breathing in water! With your plastic tubing, I don't know if you were doing differently and taking full breaths with your diaphragm because you had considerably more air to shift in the tube and considerably less chance of filling your lungs with water!

Vacuum VS water weight, that's a major part of this configuration. The 3 mil tube has less displacement of air and less water weight per meter than the 5mil tube. In the 5 mil tube he has to displace more air space at the same time lift almost twice the water weight, a stronger vacuum is required for the 5mil tube. One comment wonders about laying the tube on it's side. If you do that you'll have very little water weight so displacing the air will require less vacuum. This same concept happens when pumping water, I can pump water a much further distance horizontally than I can vertically on the same pump as the water weight is a smaller factor on the horizontal run.

I appreciate your videos.   They are entertaining and educational. So understand that it is with all due respect that I raise the following points about this video.
.
Some important things were not mentioned that influence the maximum vertical elevation someone might might get liquid water up a straw by lowering the pressure at the top and leaving the bottom open to atmospheric pressure.
.
The first thing is that by specifying liquid water, you have lowered the maximum theoretical height since water will not remain a liquid below 0.6117 KPa, and will be flashing to steam at higher pressures as long as the temperature is above 0.01 C.  All in all, with rounding, this doesn't cause a shift significant to cause the 10.3 meter figure you used to be in error, though it does mean that pulling a perfect vacuum even with the right pumps would not be possible in this setup.  I wouldn't have mentioned it if the other factors hadn't motivated me to write the comment in the first place.
.
The second thing is that insufficient consideration was given to altitude.  I did appreciate that you went to sea level to conduct the highest test. There are manyy places on earth that humans regularly are found that are below sea level.  Tau Tona gold mine in South Africa is 3.9 kilometers deep and provides a good example of why 10.3 meters is probably a little short of the maximum theoretical as well as practical limit to drinking from a straw.   Atmospheric pressure there should be well above 150 KPa. 
.
The third thing that seems worth mentioning is that the calculations of height attainable assume steady state.  Drinking from a straw is not a matter of holding liquid at a given level.  If a very low pressure is drawn initially and held, when the water reaches the point it would eventually settle at in steady state, it will not simply stop there.  It will overshoot, and depending on things like how long the straw is, the shape and smoothness, how quickly the pressure difference was created and how large the pressure difference is, as well as the density and viscosity of the water or water mixture is, the overshoot could lead to liquid reaching a much greater height than what calculation that neglect the dynamic qualities suggest would be the maximum.
.
Capillary action  would be another consideration, but I'm not certain if this would be able to assist drinking or not.

The maximum height that the water can reach is also dependent on temperature. The reason is that water's boiling point decreases with decreasing pressure. It will start to boil and release water vapor when the pressure over it decreases, which will reduce the vacuum in the sealed space. At 25C you get about 1/30 bar of pure water vapor above boiling water, and at 60C you get about 1/7 bar - which means you can get (10.3-10.3/7) meters of water at 60C. At 99C, you should not be able to get a stable water column higher than 50cm. Of course if you suck fast enough, you can temporarily exceed this limit, because the water needs a little time to release enough vapor (but the water column is likely going to be filled with gas bubbles too).

To do better than the 10.3 meter theoretical limit, you need to have a pressure differential of greater that 1atm (101.325 kPa). Rather than sucking, where at best you can create a pressure differential of (1-0) atm, try putting the straw in a bottle sealed with a rubber stopper and blowing. If you can build up a pressure of 2atm (which is about the pressure of a can of soda) or more, you will be able to do better than 10.3 meters. I'm curious about how the diameter of the straw affects the height at which you can suck the water. Nigel's first 6m attempt had a 3mm diamter straw, which was easier than the 5mm straw. This is probably due to capillary action in the straw. Capillary action is what allows trees and plants to grow taller than 10.3m. the equation for capillary action is h=2*gamma*cosTheta/(rho*g*r) where h is the height difference between the cup water level, and the straw water level. Obviously as the radius gets smaller, the h gets larger. Theoretically Nigel could suck to an infinite height, with an infinitely small diameter straw. However the physical limitations of molecules and the size of the earth limit this. I am curious to find out how long of a straw could Nigel use if the diameter is borderline unusable because of its narrow diameter.

Atmospheric pressure at sea level is about 15 psi, so you can only suck 'up' as much as the air is pushing 'down' on the fluid you're drinking. That's why pumps on wells need to be put down in the bottom of the well. They can pump out however much water you want, but there's only a certain amount water they can draw in (head) before the pump cavitates (starts drawing air/vapor out of the water) and fails to pump anymore water.

Uh, that's not the theoretical maximum. You can suck higher than that. To do so, all you need to do is to build up some momentum in the straw. I suggest that to try this out, you rig up a container preevacuated with a vacuum pump and attach the straw with a valve. Open the valve suddenly, and the liquid will go above your theoretical maximum.

Don't have a vacuum pump? Just get a couple of large containers to hold the liquid, and elevate one above the other so you can siphon the liquid from one to the other. Now lift the straw connecting the two. Keep lifting until it stops flowing. It will be above the "theoretical maximum" because momentum helps to send the liquid higher.

Also, don't forget about capillary action, although for straw-sized and larger tubes, that is pretty negligible.

It has to do with the difference between the straw's cross-section area relative to the open surface area. The atmosphere pushes on the liquid's surface creating a force that, under vacuum, pushes against the smaller cross-section in the straw. A small force on a large area translates to a bigger force on a small area. This is how a car jack works. If we could create a perfect vacuum, it wouldn't matter, unless the straw area is considerably larger than the exposed area.

3:02 - hell no. Sucking through a straw has nothing to do with your lungs or diaphragm (you'd drown if it were so) - the whole thing is done with the tongue. You start by positioning your tongue to completely "seal off" a small chamber at the front of your mouth. Then, by slowly contracting your tongue muscle and retreating it into the back of your mouth (while keeping the chamber at the front of your mouth completely sealed), you increase the volume of that chamber by an impressive percentage.

Gravitational pull is exactly what this demonstrates - the ambient air pressure versus mass under influence of gravity. If the straw were not vertical, the effort to 'suck' a liquid through it would not increase. This demonstrates that eventually, even with a perfect vacuum, gravity trumps air pressure, and the water column cannot be raised further.

It couldn't factor into it *more* extensively. ;)

That's precisely the point. :)

When you suck on a vertical straw, you're lowering the air pressure inside it. As the ambient air pressure is now higher than the air pressure inside the straw, liquid is actually *pushed* up the tube; the liquid will rise.

With a long or wide enough straw, eventually the liquid's mass is too great for ambient air pressure to raise even with a perfect vacuum up top.

Water pumps, for this reason, cannot be too far above the water level or they create a vacuum. ;)

Good point and the only reason I can think of (although the effects are pretty small) is the capillarity effect. 

Most liquids are said to "wet solid surfaces" (this is the case of water while mercury is the opposite). For wetting liquids capillarity is more pronounced the narrower the tubing and makes it so that the liquid surface in the tube "feels" a lower gas pressure than the actual pressure. That means that you could *suck* with a lesser vacuum than in the case of a thicker tube.

The pushing force of the atmosphere is working against the weight of the cola from gravity. So it's gravity as well as atmospheric pressure that decides the maximum.
What's wrong about it?

Horizontally, yes. But vertically no. 

The point is, when you suck, you're creating an area of low pressure in your mouth. The greater pressure of the atmosphere pushes down on the surface of the cola, which pushes some of the rest of the cola up the tube.

Since there's a limit to how low a pressure you could create (a complete vacuum is the utter limit, tho a human couldn't manage it), there's a limit to how high you can suck a liquid up a straw.
But if you had a thousand meter straw and sucked on one end, some liquid would be lifted on the other end. There's no limit to that length, theoretically, right?
On the bright side you can still drink coke drone your bottom floor =D

Now on the other hand if you took 2 lengths of straw, 20 meters each and placed them inside of a bottle with a stopper to make it air tight, it might only be possible to suck 10 meters of liquid with a perfect vacume, but if you BLOW air in, you pressurize the vessel and it forces the fluid UP the other straw for a much longer distance. This is why water tanks on tall buildings, and water towers, use compressors to PUSH fluid up, instead of suction to suck them up.

What i'm trying to point out is that the maximum length is 10.3m (or whatever number you calculate) plus the length of the straw submerged in the water.  If you want a 100 meter straw, you simply need to drink from the bottom of a 95 meter well.
It should be the pressure at the bottom of the vessel that governs the theoretical maximum, which could be higher than atmospheric pressure.

That's very easy to find out if you have a diameter/radius of the straw, since it's essentially a cylinder, and volume = height × (π×R×R)
- so if it was a 5 mm diameter you'd need about 0.785 litre of fluid to fill it, or 0.283 litre if it was 3mm (and the bottle used looked more like a 0.5 L one)

Although it is impossible to raise a column of water that is more than 10.3m tall using atmospheric pressure, it should be possible to raise a shorter column of water much farther. This could be done by drawing some amount (less than 10.3m!) of liquid from the reservoir, then removing the bottom of the straw from the liquid and continuing to suck. However, there is still a fundamental limit for each column height due to decreasing pressure with altitude. (For 1m of water this is several km up.)

I'll not disagree that "begs the question" is a semi-common publicly made mistake, especially on youtube, but it is still wrong. Begging the question is a type of logical fallacy in which a proposition relies on an implicit premise within itself to establish the truth of that same proposition. In other words, one of the premises necessary for the validation of the proposition is only itself valid if the proposition is valid. There's no anthropomorphism about it.
"Begs the question" is a common expression, it anthropomorphises the situation in that, it suggest the situation wants you to ask that question.

It sounds like brute force to me, only.

Because Force is Pressure per Surface Area. More surface area, more force is needed (sucking power) to deliver the same negative pressure. 

This force is greater for a wider tube than for a narrower one. So, to drive fluid up a wide tube you need more force in order to reach a perfect vacuum, than you would need for a narrow tube.

But no matter the force, the perfect vacuum - fluid equilibrium will be found at a fluid column height of aprox 10.3 m.
Don't forget that you also have head losses in the pipe :)

I completely understand your point and you are partially right. BUT, it isn't the surface tension alone that is keeping the drink in the straw. If you take the straw with some liquid in it out of the drink and you take the straw out of your mouth, the liquid will fall out. But if you keep it in your mouth and hold the pressure difference, the surface tension will form a membrane which the air pushes BECAUSE of the pressure difference. The surface tension alone won't hold the liquid in the straw.

You seem to be ignoring that the straw is kept in the mouth and there is a significant difference in pressure. Therefore the air is pressing the water up from underneath. "the size of the tubes ~.02 mm should only support a water column of ~0.7m"
Not quite like that. The pull-capacity of capillary action depends on the size of the open-air orifices, not the size of the tubes below it. The orifices (stomata) are of a few microns to sub-micron size for high trees (50 to 100m) (with inverse correlation), with hydraulic tension (at leaf) in the 1-2 MPa range (enough to pull the column and sustain root osmosis). Tracheid density increase also plays a part.

I think a) is more significant than you think and b) and c) are less significant. In fact, some trees live in places where the osmotic pressure is not in their favour so they need extra pressure to gain water against osmosis. I don't think capillary forces are significant because the size of the tubes ~.02 mm should only support a water column ~0.7m high.

3 aspects: a) Transpirational pull as water evaporates from leaves, reducing pressure of water at top of xylem tubes, alone can only support column equal to atmospheric pressure; for water 10.3 m (34 ft). Additional upward forces b) capillary pressure, is significant and a few atmospheric pressures worth, and c) root pressure, the osmotic pressure from the soil into the roots - for some plants this is 5 atm, so could support column 10.3m x 5. Combined effects suffice.

Small correction; this isn't about breath.  Suction in drinking isn't a lung and diaphragm thing.  You aren't inhaling - the suction is created by the musculature of the mouth.  You mentioned this in the video, and this post mentions it again.  Drinking through a straw involves sealing the oral cavity and using check and tongue muscles to create the low pressure.  Babies actually have fat pads in their checks to help them effortlessly create suction.  Buccal fat pads recede in toddlers.

It isn't a function of the area of the straw. This is because both the force due to the pressure difference, and the mass of the liquid being sucked up, are directly proportional to the area of the straw. This is captured in the equations at the end of the video. :)

Good question. Actually, if we ignore friction, the diameter of the tube doesn't matter. This is because both the force due to the pressure difference, and the mass of the liquid, are directly proportional to the cross sectional area of the straw. Hence, the area cancels out, so the diameter doesn't matter. This is captured in the equations at the end of the video.

Capillary action might slightly increase how high you could suck the liquid, by providing an additional (but small) force upward.

To first approximation (ignoring compression of the pockets of air with liquid resting on it, not sure exactly what the effect of that would be), you'll still be able to get a maximum of 10.3 meters of liquid, plus however much air you want.

Good question. As long as we're ignoring viscosity of the liquid and friction the liquid and the straw, then the diameter of the tube doesn't matter. This is because both the force due to the pressure difference, and the mass of the liquid in the tube, are directly proportional to the cross sectional area of the straw. Hence, the area cancels out, so the diameter doesn't matter. This is captured in the equations at the end of the video.

You're incorrect in regards to the trees fact...yes capillary action has a small role to play, but the majority of the work being done to move water up that high is through the "cohesion-tension theory", where pores (stomata) of the plant's leaves allow water to evaporate out into the atmosphere. This evaporation creates a miniscus around the pore, and since water is extremely cohesive, i.e. it "sticks" to itself well, the tension in the miniscus pulls water from the roots up through the plant.

@PapaT104 Actually, it wouldn't.  The theoretical maximum of 10.3 meters assumes atmospheric pressure and a perfect vacuum at the top.  So you have a pressure differential of 1 atmosphere.  If you push it up from the bottom and use more than 2 atmospheres of pressure you will have more than the same amount of pressure differential.  This is how water is pumped from wells and such, they place a pump down in the well which is able to pump the water much further than 10.3 meters.  Or oil rigs.

@IvarHuisman Nope, water pressure is determined by the amount of water above you - or your point of reference - not by the amount of water in total. Otherwise the water pressure at the bottom of a small pool would be less than the pressure in the ocean at the same depth. Still you don't need a column 10 meters high because you are not interested in the total air pressure but rather in chances in pressure and even with lower levels of water you get chances in the hight based on the pressure.

You wouldnt need a 10 meter long barometer to do the air pressure scale thing, you'd need a very wide one so it can hold a lot of water. But your measurements wouldn't be very accurate that way though.

@1veritasium Well trees suck water by capillary action. As of physics, as you reduce the diameter of the straw you limit the available motions that liquid inside the straw makes during the flow. For instance, a larger diameter allows for turbulent flow (chaotic flow, determined by friction) whereas a smaller diameter only allows for laminar flow. Also viscosity of the liquid plays a role. Total behaviour can roughly be estimated by Reynolds number.

@1veritasium with a larger inner diameter, the total volume of liquid inside the tube for any given height is greater.  The larger volume of liquid weighs more.  In order to drink from the straw, you have to apply a suction force with your mouth/lungs equal to the force caused by the weight of the liquid.  If you used a long thin hose, you could go more than 6 meters.

With that larger hose, you could calculate precisely how much Nigel sucks by measuring the maximum height he can get the liquid.
